text: [Music]
hi I'm Hannes i'm a principal consultant working for Access in Belgium and I'm
joined here today by Eli Holderness to talk about responsibly using GP records
for research purposes eli would you care to introduce yourselves to the audience hello yes my
name is Eli i am a research software advocate at the Bennett Institute based out of the University of Oxford and the
main thing that the Bennett Institute does is produce uh administer build design open safely which is what I'm
going to talk about with Hannah today now just for the reference of the audience can you maybe explain a little
bit what open safely is what it does um so that we have a little bit of an idea
what what we're talking about so the way I like to talk about it is that open safely is both a a philosophy of
research sort of um data science being used for research purposes and it's also
a set of tooling that enables that philosophy to be carried out so the idea
is that if you've got lots of sensitive data so at the moment we have access to about 58 million rows of 58 um of
patient data in the UK provided by the Royal College of GPS if you want to use that data to draw
insights about you know public health you want to make sure that that data is handled responsibly with respect to
patients privacy um and that the tooling is in place to make that easy and at the
moment um what we have is yeah we have access to about 58 million rows of patient data and we are building we have
built we've got it's up and running papers are being uh written based off the back of research done using the open
safety tooling um that's what it is but the philosophy of it is the idea that if
you've got this patient data if you've got sensitive data and you want to do you want to run code against it you want to query it you want to do statistical
analysis either you have to move that data out of whatever secure environment it's stored in or you have to take the
analysis to the data and so that's what open safety does is all of the research
code that is ever run against this data that we have access to happens behind a
sort of secure environment that's really interesting to me because
the way I just understand what you just said is instead of giving people access to the
data so that they can query it themselves and draw their own conclusions Mhm you are going to be
operating their code against the data and they never see the actual data they
only see the results of their analysis is that is that how it works yeah pretty much so if you are a researcher and you
want to write a study and you want to use open safety to do it you contact us you get approval for your study so
there's several governing bodies that we need to go and talk to about that nhs England is one of them we have our own approvals process sort of pre-approvals
process once you have been cleared to run that project you get put in touch
with one of our co-pilots or our co-pilot team which are sort of firstline research support um you write
some code publicly on GitHub you don't have to make the repository public until you've actually published any papers but
you you write code on GitHub and the way that that code ends up being run against
the real data is that you submit it to us through our open safely jobs server
you schedule a job and then we take that code um which is some of which will be
written in our domain specific query language which we wrote specifically for working with electronic healthcare
records um which is it's incredibly cool and it is open source and I will love to talk more about it uh you write code in
that query language that is then eventually compiled to SQL that runs against the specific database that we
have access to the secure back end um and all of that all of the code that
makes that happen is open source as well so our job site our job runner all of these things
um and that code then runs in the secure environment and we as the open safety
team have access to certain things within that remote uh that secure environment so we've got some limited
telemetry that we can get out of there um we can know why jobs failed or if
they succeeded things like that but we don't even have direct access to look at that data it's super locked down so your
code has run you've extracted data from the database into sort of working memory essentially there and run
transformations on it you've run your analyses any statistical models and then the results of that are aggregated and
made available to output checkers and output checkers are trained professionals usually researchers
themselves who look through the results of what you've done um which might be
like tables and graphs and things like that and check whether any of what
you've output is disclosive um could be used to identify individuals or small
groups of individuals um and that's like there are absolutely hard and fast rules
about how that's done but there's also some element of judgment calls about whether or not well it's okay that this
number was referred to only a really small number of patients because we expected that as part of the study design um so that's a key part of the
process mhm and that's something that's standard across any kind of research that deals with sensitive data is is
output checking i mean you you can even see it in in systems where you are trying to measure employee satisfaction
it's it's a place where I've run across this and if you start adding parameters
to your queries as soon as you would get close enough to being able to identify
one of your employees like who has set this one thing yeah you have to shut that down you have to shut that down and
basically that's what you have to do for records that are way more sensitive than employee satisfaction right like um as
far as I know my data is in that back end um so there's with GP records in the
UK there are two main suppliers of electronic healthcare records software um and they are TPP and EMIS and in the
past Open Safely has had um software running in both of those backends um secure backends at the moment we only
have TPP for funding reasons and I don't know if my which one of those two my GP
record data isn't about me but if I wanted to I could go well I know that I had an appointment on this time at this
date and I was diagnosed with this or I was prescribed this or whatever and I could potentially use that information
that I have about myself to like explore my own records like remotely but the
thing is that I would never get that information back out because the output checkers would go "Well that's not that's not good you can't be can't be
doing that because I could do it about myself and maybe you could argue that I should be able to do that about myself i
shouldn't be able to do it about let's say a politician in my country whose some of whose medical history is known
um so output checking is a sort of key part of how we preserve privacy of this
data and that at the moment is still done by humans who are yes it's still done um at the moment at time of
recording by humans within the Bennett Institute um that doesn't scale event
like that doesn't scale infinitely so we're looking at better ways to have that output checking be performed by a
broader set of people um obviously having people outside the Bennett Institute do it as well reduces the
chance that anybody could think that there's bias um because obviously we're also we're doing science here so we want
it to be as as open and as sort of democratic as possible you base these studies off of the general GP data
that's in that database mhm what kind of research are we looking at here what
what's the type of studies that are being performed um against this so at
the moment open safely started during early days of CO um and at the moment
what we have is we have permissions for any studies to be run that refer to that that are related to CO so we have
studies about things like rates of certain drug prescriptions during COVID rates of incidence of certain um
diseases linked secondary conditions obviously we've got sort of it one of the primary arguments for having this
data available for research in the first place during COVID was do the vaccines work who's getting them do we see side
effects so lots of things like that m um as we move away from the period in time
when that stuff was was considered most critical um we're looking at at time of
recording we don't have permissions for non-COVID related research proposals to
be granted for with open safely but work is being done to make that happen so
ideally maybe sometime this year maybe sometime next year I'm not I'm not qualified to say definitively but we'll
have permissions for any kind of research that you think yeah anything any question you can ask that you think
might be answered with this kind of data but it's interesting because this data is not it's not clinical research data
it's data that has been collected for the purpose of GPS being able to do their jobs and provide primary healthare
so does that mean that maybe there is some data lacking in the system
or some data that is not really structured for things that these researchers are doing with it well one
of interesting things so we have access to this GP data there are also linked data sets so like a renal registry data
set and sort of specialist things like that and all of these data sets have
different formats and different you know um ways of accessing them which means that when you as a researcher write code
against some of this data if you're doing it directly in the the model that is not the open safely model the
standard model where you are sort of given direct access access to a synonymized curated data set your code
is very bespoke and can only run on that that database and that data set essentially because the the schemas are
wrong yeah and so what open safely has done is try and solve some of that problem of you know because it's these
all these disperate sort of schema and things like that scheata sorry um we've
written this domain specific query language that will compile to the right kind of SQL and the right kind of things
um what are some of the intricacies of of this this DSL that you created so
it's built on top of Python um and which is just a choice we've made because it
was the research language i mean obviously you have um you have Python you have R and you have STA as some of
the like three of the most commonly written languages for doing statistical research and Python out of those three
was the one that the tech team were most familiar with um because it's also a software industry language in a way that
sort of R and STA are much more specialized into their research domains um and what it is is it looks very much
like Python with some sort of weird bits of magic sprinkled in um sort of messing around with Python internals and things
to make certain things work it's really really cool um and the language is um electronic healthcare record query
language eh HRQL to to rhyme with circle
and what you do as a researcher is you write this code and it looks very much like Python and then what happens is
that is um sort of serialized into a query model and then that query model is then analyzed to create essentially um
eventually a SQL query and what kind of database it is running against is part of the configuration so for TPP I
believe it's a MySQL database and so the version of Urkl that runs when you
submit code to run against that database is going oh I want to output my SQL SQL but let's say another data provider
might have Postgres and if there was a version of open safely running there it would spit out different SQL but the
idea is that you can write a query once and then run it in a variety of different environments and get back the
results you expect so you could theoretically in the future run the same programs that your researchers have
written against different healthare providers exactly or possibly even different countries or is that
completely out of scope who can say i mean I know that there are like we could the research that one of the reasons
that I I like to delineate open safely into a philosophy of research and also this tooling is that that philosophy of
research that you write hypothesis-driven code and then you submit it to be run and then you get
back some aggregated output checked results that is not by any means
specific to healthcare you could do open safely pensions to analyze how people's pension investments happen and and which
groups are more likely to choose pensions that have this characteristic or whatever and that's also sensitive
data you could do you know open safely we have an initiative called open safety schools um which is about using that
research philosophy to investigate education data which is another domain where there sort of very fragmented
um bespoke data sets in all sorts of places across the country the tooling to enable it might
change because it doesn't necessarily make sense to have something that's very specialized towards electronic
healthcare records being used to analyze pension data mhm but there is absolutely
like huge potential for this model to be used across different domains um one of
the big challenges is that if you are committed to data not leaving the center in which it is held how do you do
linkage across different data sets right yeah which is not something that I know much about um but it's it's a common
problem against across sort of all sorts of sensitive data research um and the
trusted research environments which are the the other model that's open safely is sort of it's open safely is referred
to sometimes as a TR but it operates in a slightly different way whereas most um
trusted research environments uh you as a researcher once you're given approval to have access to the data you are given
access to curated well curated pseudonmized But one thing about that is that who
curated that data who pseudonmized it it's not raw there is already in a very
technical term bias introduced into what you as a researcher are allowed to access because there has to be in order
for you to be able to view it directly but if you don't if you don't have to view it directly you don't have to pseudonymize it or or curate it first
right does this whole process impact the way that research is performed because if
since you don't get access to the source data I can imagine that as a researcher you have to adjust your approach you
cannot just go and click around and explore Yes what you have yeah I there is definitely a sort of culture shock
almost um aspect to it where researchers will learn like they'll sort of get
started with open safely and it's and it is a very different experience that they can't sort of run exploratory queries
and get results back very in a very far like in a very fast feedback loop um and
that is a trade-off like it is in some regards less usable but it does also prevent you as a researcher from doing
what's known as P hacking which is I have a hypothesis and the data doesn't quite support it maybe if I exclude like
that group of people and make up a justification as to why I should exclude them and maybe exclude that group of
people and maybe only take results from that I can oh suddenly now I have managed to um massage the data into
supporting my hypothesis you can't do that with open safely because the feedback loops are longer i mean you
could in theory it would just take forever and also because the code that you write if you ever publish a paper
using open safely uh like off the back of research you did using open safely we
require that you make your code public as well and anybody could really look at that and go why did you exclude those
those groups why did you exclude what's your scientific basis for doing that and it made my hypothesis correct is not a
scientific basis so it's it enforces you as a researcher to take a hypothesis-driven approach approach
where you have to clearly upfront state what are you doing what do you
expect to see from it um and you get the results back you you can't you can't
fiddle with things in quite the same way basically forces people to think about
their hypo hypothesis a lot harder well I mean I I like to imagine that
researchers are all thinking about their hypothesis really hard it does so something that this sort of touches on
is that researchers and research as a profession is a really difficult thing because as a researcher you want to do
good science and people have got into doing research nobody goes into like doing epidemiology because they just you
know gets paid exactly well maybe there are some but as a researcher you want to
do good science you want to you don't want to be doing things where you're like I need to massage the data to prove to like to retrofit my hypothesis but if
you don't like if you don't have positive results to publish a paper your university is going to drop you like you
you need to also have a career in order to keep paying the bills but maybe you just don't maybe
you're asking questions and you're proving things that are really useful like there is no link between this COVID
vaccine and increased rates of pneumonia or something pulled that one off the top of my head um that's useful to know but it's not
the kind of thing that's easy to publish and get you know a claim for industry
sort of um professional status for and so as a researcher you're caught
between this rock and a hard place of well I need results in order to continue having a career and continue to have
like maybe tenure somewhere um versus the results just aren't like the my
hypothesis just aren't bearing out um and so I guess open safely is is tilting
the scales more towards you actually have to ask the right question upfront um yeah so that's another interesting

does that run on who manages all that infrastructure who's funding that so
when you as a researcher write code uh cool code you can test it locally and we
